sect3.title: Typed properties
Arrow functions
Limited return type covariance and argument type contravariance

informalexample.programlisting:
<?php
$array['key'] ??= computeDefault();
// is roughly equivalent to
if (!isset($array['key'])) {
    $array['key'] = computeDefault();
}
?>

sect3.title: Numeric literal separator
sect3.para:
Numeric literals can contain underscores between digits.
<?php 6.674_083e-11; // float 299_792_458; // decimal 0xCAFE_F00D; // hexadecimal 0b0101_1111; // binary ?>

sect3.title: Weak references
sect3.para: Weak references allow the programmer to retain a reference to an object that does not prevent the object from being destroyed.

sect3.title: Allow exceptions from __toString()
sect3.para: Throwing exceptions from __toString() is now permitted. Previously this resulted in a fatal error. Existing recoverable fatal errors in string conversions have been converted to Error exceptions.

sect2.title: CURL
sect2.para: CURLFile now supports stream wrappers in addition to plain file names, if the extension has been built against libcurl >= 7.56.0.

sect2.title: Filter
sect2.para: The FILTER_VALIDATE_FLOAT filter now supports the min_range and max_range options, with the same semantics as FILTER_VALIDATE_INT.

sect2.title: FFI
sect2.para: FFI is a new extension, which provides a simple way to call native functions, access native variables, and create/access data structures defined in C libraries.

sect2.title: GD
sect2.para: Added the IMG_FILTER_SCATTER image filter to apply a scatter filter to images.

sect2.title: Hash
sect2.para: Added crc32c hash using Castagnoli's polynomial. This CRC32 variant is used by storage systems, such as iSCSI, SCTP, Btrfs and ext4.

sect2.title: Multibyte String
sect2.para: Added the mb_str_split function, which provides the same functionality as str_split, but operating on code points rather than bytes.

sect2.title: OPcache
sect2.para: Support for preloading code has been added.

sect2.title: Regular Expressions (Perl-Compatible)
sect2.para: The preg_replace_callback and preg_replace_callback_array functions now accept an additional flags argument, with support for the PREG_OFFSET_CAPTURE and PREG_UNMATCHED_AS_NULL flags. This influences the format of the matches array passed to the callback function.

sect2.title: PDO
sect2.para: The username and password can now be specified as part of the PDO DSN for the mysql, mssql, sybase, dblib, firebird and oci drivers. Previously this was only supported by the pgsql driver. If a username/password is specified both in the constructor and the DSN, the constructor takes precedence.

It is now possible to escape question marks in SQL queries to avoid them being interpreted as parameter placeholders. Writing ?? allows sending a single question mark to the database and e.g. use the PostgreSQL JSON key exists (?) operator.

sect2.title: PDO_SQLite
sect2.para: PDOStatement::getAttribute(PDO::SQLITE_ATTR_READONLY_STATEMENT) allows checking whether the statement is read-only, i.e. if it doesn't modify the database.
PDO::setAttribute(PDO::SQLITE_ATTR_EXTENDED_RESULT_CODES, true) enables the use of SQLite3 extended result codes in PDO::errorInfo and PDOStatement::errorInfo.

sect2.title: SQLite3
sect2.para: Added SQLite3::lastExtendedErrorCode to fetch the last extended result code.
Added SQLite3::enableExtendedResultCodes($enable = true), which will make SQLite3::lastErrorCode return extended result codes.

sect3.title: strip_tags() with array of tag names
sect3.para:
strip_tags now also accepts an array of allowed tags: instead of strip_tags($str, '

') you can now write strip_tags($str, ['a', 'p']).

sect3.title: Custom object serialization
Array merge functions without arguments
sect3.para: array_merge and array_merge_recursive may now be called without any arguments, in which case they will return an empty array. This is useful in conjunction with the spread operator, e.g. array_merge(...$arrays).

sect3.title: proc_open function
sect3.para:
proc_open now accepts an array instead of a string for the command. In this case the process will be opened directly (without going through a shell) and PHP will take care of any necessary argument escaping.
<?php proc_open(['php', '-r', 'echo "Hello World\n";'], $descriptors, $pipes); ?>

sect3.title: argon2i(d) without libargon
sect3.para: password_hash now has the argon2i and argon2id implementations from the sodium extension when PHP is built without libargon.
